H) The creation of the Napoleonic Code

This question refers to the following information. Read the following excerpt. Never were talents of the highest genius of the most exalted kind, more profusely bestowed upon a human being. The genius of Napoleon is astounding. All branches of human knowledge seemed alike familiar to his gigantic mind. His conversations at St. Helena, scattered through the numerous and voluminous memorials of those who gleaned them, are replete with intensest interest. During the long agony of his imprisonment and his death, he conversed with perfect freedom upon the events of his marvelous career, and upon all those subjects or morals, politics, and religion, which most deeply concern the welfare of our race. There is no mind which will not be invigorated by familiarity with these profound thoughts, expressed with so much glow of feeling and energy of diction. —John S. C. Abbott, historian, Napoleon at St. Helena, 1855 Which of the following actions of Napoleon does the author seem to be ignoring the hypocrisy of in his examination of the high mindedness and praiseworthiness of Napoleon?

A) His manipulation of the press for political gain
B) His conquest of Europe and use of the Continental System
C) His imposition of French culture on conquered territories
D) The invasion of Haiti to stop a slave revolt there
E) His establishment of the Bank of France
F) His self-appointment as Emperor of France
G) Promoting soldiers and government workers based upon their merits only
H) The creation of the Napoleonic Code

This question refers to the following information. Read the following excerpt. Never were talents of the highest genius of the most exalted kind, more profusely bestowed upon a human being. The genius of Napoleon is astounding. All branches of human knowledge seemed alike familiar to his gigantic mind. His conversations at St. Helena, scattered through the numerous and voluminous memorials of those who gleaned them, are replete with intensest interest. During the long agony of his imprisonment and his death, he conversed with perfect freedom upon the events of his marvelous career, and upon all those subjects or morals, politics, and religion, which most deeply concern the welfare of our race. There is no mind which will not be invigorated by familiarity with these profound thoughts, expressed with so much glow of feeling and energy of diction. —John S. C. Abbott, historian, Napoleon at St. Helena, 1855 Which of the following actions of Napoleon does the author seem to be ignoring the hypocrisy of in his examination of the high mindedness and praiseworthiness of Napoleon?

B) His conquest of Europe and use of the Continental System

E) His establishment of the Bank of France
F) His self-appointment as Emperor of France
G) Promoting soldiers and government workers based upon their merits only
H) The creation of the Napoleonic Code

This question refers to the following information. Read the following excerpt. Never were talents of the highest genius of the most exalted kind, more profusely bestowed upon a human being. The genius of Napoleon is astounding. All branches of human knowledge seemed alike familiar to his gigantic mind. His conversations at St. Helena, scattered through the numerous and voluminous memorials of those who gleaned them, are replete with intensest interest. During the long agony of his imprisonment and his death, he conversed with perfect freedom upon the events of his marvelous career, and upon all those subjects or morals, politics, and religion, which most deeply concern the welfare of our race. There is no mind which will not be invigorated by familiarity with these profound thoughts, expressed with so much glow of feeling and energy of diction. —John S. C. Abbott, historian, Napoleon at St. Helena, 1855 Which of the following actions of Napoleon does the author seem to be ignoring the hypocrisy of in his examination of the high mindedness and praiseworthiness of Napoleon?

A) His manipulation of the press for political gain
B) His conquest of Europe and use of the Continental System
C) His imposition of French culture on conquered territories
D) The invasion of Haiti to stop a slave revolt there
E) His establishment of the Bank of France
F) His self-appointment as Emperor of France
G) Promoting soldiers and government workers based upon their merits only
H) The creation of the Napoleonic Code

This question refers to the following information. Read the following excerpt. Never were talents of the highest genius of the most exalted kind, more profusely bestowed upon a human being. H) The creation of the Napoleonic Code

H) The creation of the Napoleonic Code

This question refers to the following information. Read the following excerpt. Never were talents of the highest genius of the most exalted kind, more profusely bestowed upon a human being. The genius of Napoleon is astounding. All branches of human knowledge seemed alike familiar to his gigantic mind. During the long agony of his imprisonment and his death, he conversed with perfect freedom upon the events of his marvelous career, and upon all those subjects or morals, politics, and religion, which most deeply concern the welfare of our race. There is no mind which will not be invigorated by familiarity with these profound thoughts, expressed with so much glow of feeling and energy of diction. —John S. C. B) His conquest of Europe and use of the Continental System

D) The invasion of Haiti to stop a slave revolt there
E) His establishment of the Bank of France
F) His self-appointment as Emperor of France
G) Promoting soldiers and government workers based upon their merits only
H) The creation of the Napoleonic Code

This question refers to the following information. Read the following excerpt. Never were talents of the highest genius of the most exalted kind, more profusely bestowed upon a human being. The genius of Napoleon is astounding. All branches of human knowledge seemed alike familiar to his gigantic mind. His conversations at St. Helena, scattered through the numerous and voluminous memorials of those who gleaned them, are replete with intensest interest. During the long agony of his imprisonment and his death, he conversed with perfect freedom upon the events of his marvelous career, and upon all those subjects or morals, politics, and religion, which most deeply concern the welfare of our race. There is no mind which will not be invigorated by familiarity with these profound thoughts, expressed with so much glow of feeling and energy of diction. —John S. C. Abbott, historian, Napoleon at St. Helena, 1855 Which of the following actions of Napoleon does the author seem to be ignoring the hypocrisy of in his examination of the high mindedness and praiseworthiness of Napoleon?

A) His manipulation of the press for political gain
B) His conquest of Europe and use of the Continental System
C) His imposition of French culture on conquered territories
D) The invasion of Haiti to stop a slave revolt there
E) His establishment of the Bank of France
F) His self-appointment as Emperor of France
G) Promoting soldiers and government workers based upon their merits only
H) The creation of the Napoleonic Code
